instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Charger light green, but switches off after a while. Power rails stay as below whether light is off or on.

No fans

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> = 0V, no short to ground
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> &  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0V, no short to ground
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_MCP</SIGNAL> = 1.1V

MCP does not heat up.

Anything left to look at other than blaming the MCP?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.4V which could indicate an issue with the SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Using a REAL APPLE 85W charger? These do not auto power on, need to short power on pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[USER="289"]smiba[/USER] - Its actually 8.41 according to my multimeter, which isn't all that accurate, though it performs amazingly well for the pos it is.

[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] I'm using a real charger. Don't own a fake. I tried both shorting the pads at <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> (without keyboard cable inserted) and using the power button with the cable inserted. <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.4V.
I swapped the magsafe to rule that out - no change.

Further: According to the customer the problem started out of the blue, no moisture damage spotted on the board or inside the laptop, though I havent completely disassembled it. It was fairly dusty at the fans (smoker), but not clogged up and the fans still spin ok by hand.

edit: seems green charger light switching off as mentioned earlier might just have been due to an imperfect connection between charger and magsafe board. I havent seen the light turn off anymore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high? Resistance to GND on 3V42?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 25193"]<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high? Resistance to GND on 3V42?[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is high (3.39V)

resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present? Replace <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> just to be sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is at 3.3V
PP1V2R1V05_S5 is at 1.1V

<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> replaced, no change. (I checked the cap with my ESR meter, its 362uF and 0.0ESR, so was almost certainly fine to start with).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Checked all rails for shorts? Check <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> while pressing the power button, is there a pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>

Is the resistance for the PPVCORE rail normally that low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Vcore is normal. This is starting to look like an SMC or MCP problem :( Have you tried booting from a charged battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I charged the battery with this board, verified that its working (bat gave ~7V first, ~12 after charging a while). Going to let it charge a little longer, but right now there is no fan spin when trying to power it up with the battery in (tried with magsafe in and out). Not very hopeful.
Can I check wheter its the SMC or MCP somehow? The SMC I could probably replace, though I'm still waiting for my jig to show up from China and have yet to do my first replacement, but it should wind up here eventually.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMS_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> toggling when you press power?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Toggling? As in, being pulled back to ground when I hit the button and coming back up when I release it? If so, yes it is

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Same for the <SIGNAL>SLP_S3</SIGNAL>? If nothing happens there check the RTC Xtal for 32KHz

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> has 0V, no short to ground. Thats another one that should be generated by the MCP, yes?

I think the crystal is working, I've added screencaps of my scope for both pins



[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALIN</SIGNAL>.jpg - <SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALIN</SIGNAL>" type="full" width="320px"]25378._xfImport[/ATTACH]
<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALIN</SIGNAL>


[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALOUT</SIGNAL>.jpg - <SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALOUT</SIGNAL>" type="full" width="320px"]25379._xfImport[/ATTACH]
<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALOUT</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm seeing 25MHz, you need to measure RTC Xtal and that should have 32KHz

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Boardview lists multiple XTals, I figured you wanted to see <SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALOUT</SIGNAL> or IN.
Is it <SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL_R</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL> at Y5010 you want? Its the one right by the SMC.
If so, reading is below. Schematic says its a 20MHZ crystal, so says the scope as well.
I dont know how to measure the 32KHz its supposed to be putting out, I haven't tested a crystal beyond checking whether there is a wave or not.

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL>.jpg - Click image for larger version  Name:	<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL>.jpg Views:	1 Size:	34.7 KB ID:	25417" type="full" width="30%"]25417._xfImport[/ATTACH]

<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL>

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL_R</SIGNAL>.jpg - Click image for larger version  Name:	<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL_R</SIGNAL>.jpg Views:	1 Size:	35.8 KB ID:	25418" type="full" width="30%"]25418._xfImport[/ATTACH]

<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL_R</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I got my measurements mixed up earlier, measured at the wrong crystal. Sorry about that. Here's the actual RTC XTAL:


[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALIN</SIGNAL>.jpg" type="full" width="320px"]25451._xfImport[/ATTACH]
<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALIN</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>RTC_CLK32K_XTALOUT_R</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - missing <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, that pretty much leaves a dead MCP or SMC.
